title: holidays abroad normal three years flight centre
story: Even then things may never be the same again and travellers could be forced to undergo coronavirus testing before and after flights.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesFlight Centre chief executive Graham ‘Skroo’ Turner said that just how fast the industry bounces back depends on government policy.He told ABC radio: “Its really up to the government on this sort of thing, andthey ease restrictions it will come back fairly quickly.“Maybe  months to two yearsmight be back to  per cent, but itll probably be three years before its back to pre-COVID levels.”In many countries such as Australia overseas travellers have to self-fund a two-week quarantine period.But Mr Turner said quarantine will put off some people from travelling but he suggested a better idea would be to test travellers before and after they fly.He said: “I think the protocols, pretty soon, will be to the stage where it will be probably nearly as safe as a two-week quarantine in a hotel.”Since the coronavirus outbreak Flight Centre has stood down around , staff around the world.Airlines including Virgin and Qantas have also been forced to shed thousands of jobs as flights have been grounded.British Airways could axe , jobs due to the pandemic.The UK government has announced plans to introduce a traffic-light system that will be used to rate other countries coronavirus risk.People travelling to Green or Amber countries - which includes most of Europe - will soon no be longer required to quarantine for  days on theirto the UK.There are also plans to set up air bridges to allow for two-way travel between certain destinations with low transmission rates.The foreign office continues to advise against all but essential travel for the time being, but many Brits will now be hoping to get a summer holiday in after all.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk spiders 21 british spiders
story: But what are the spiders most likely to creepy crawl in your home  Here is everything we know.Black lace weavers are usually found inside homes all year round.They are found on walls, fencing and clutter around the garden and are most common autumn when males leave their webs to find females.They can be found indoors after heavy rainfall when their home becomes flooded. They are harmless to humans. Buzzing spiders are found all over Britain but are more predominant in the south. They are rarely found on the ground but mostly in shrubbery and over the foliage of trees.Buzzing spiders get their names from when the males vibrate on leaves to attract females.The cardinal spider is the largest spider in the UK.Otherwise known as Tegenaria parietina, some of these spiders have been recorded to have a leg span of cm.The name cardinal was appropriated from a legend that dates back to the th century when Cardinal Wolsey was scared by the spider at Hampton Court.The spider is fairly rare in Europe and is found more commonly in the south of England.Most live in buildings or walls and like all spiders live in houses.They can withstand very dry conditions and survive for months without sustenance.The cardinal spider is capable of biting, although bites have rarely been recorded.The nip is believed to be completely harmless and painless to humans.The cave spider is roughly mm to mm long and can be found around the UK all year round.These spiders are most likely to be found in caves, tunnels and spots with little to no sunlight.Cellar spiders are also known as Daddy Longleg Spiders.Their spindly bodies can be up to mm in .They can be found in homes all year round with males living up to two years and females can live up to three years.The common crab spider is most common in Britain from March to August in low-lying vegetation. Terryingly they eat their prey by jumping on their backs and piercing them with their fangs.This spider can be seen from July to October in any structure where it can build a web.Common orb-weavers mostly eat small insects and flies. They get their name from the orb shape of their web.This tiny green spider can be found in the UK from April to October. They are found in low growing bushes and hedgerows. Cucumber spiders are native to the UK.Cupboard spiders can be found incupboards. Their colouring ies from dark purple to brown or black.While these spiders do bite their bite isnt known to cause serious symptoms.European garden spiders can be found in woodland and garden across the UK from June to October. False widow spiders are found in outbuildings and homes all year round.They are believed to have arrived in Britain in  from the Canary Islands.Despite their name being similar to the deadly black widow spider, their bites are way less harmful.The four spot spider can be seen in Britain in tall grass during the summer and autumn. They have four white spots on their back giving them their name.This spider is the one you will see most common in the autumn.The giant house spider lives in sheds, attics, homes and out buildings. It can survive for several months without any food or water. They are seen all year round but mate in the autumn time. Britain has its own terrying version of the huntsman spider. They can be found in woodlands and are very rare. They are generally spotted from May to September in Southern England and Ireland.These tiny spiders can be found in low vegetation from May to September. They get their name from jumping on their prey rather than collecting it in a web.This rather large spider is found in Wales and England from June to SeptemberThey live in hedgerows and in long grass.These little guys are known to be very harmless and can be found in the foliage from trees.These strange-looking spiders can be found near water and are mostly seen from May to September.These very dramatic looking spiders are found in England and Wales from April to October and live ion low growing vegetation. Sector spiders are found in homes hanging from window frames and live inside all year round.These strangely adorable looking spiders are twice the size of a standard jumping spider. While they can bite, their bites are not venomous and they will usually run away from you instead.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pregnant brit australia fundraising
story: Alana Smith, originally from England, has been in Adelaide, Australia on a tourist visa after adoring partner Josh Hayes died during the coronavirus lockdown.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesHer friends from New Zealand are now attempting to support the five-month pregnant Brit while she stays in Australia to remain close to her husbands family, unable to work to support herself while carrying their child.Former co-workers at disability support organisation Spectrum Care in Wellington, New Zealand have set up a Give a Little page and a relay race to help her through financial stre.I am in Australia on a tourist visa, so it means the world at the moment, she told Stuff.I am unable to work and there is so much uncertainty around the coronavirus in the UK.Having Joshs family here for me was really important to feel as close as possible to him.You can suddenly feel very alone.The page has so far raised over , and the soon-to-be mum is thankful not just for her friends fundraising efforts, but also for keeping her going during this devastating period. She said: A lot of the guys have been so supportive, messaging me every day.That is definitely a support that has kept me going.Laura Wild, who set up the page, met Alana at Spectrum Care and they have remained friends ever since, even after Alana moved back to the UK and then Australia.Laura said: A lot of people came here, and they and their families remember Alana.Now Laura and her friends are determined to help out their backpacking chum.The Give a Little page reads: The money will be used for anything Alana and baby may need: a hot chocolate with a friend, a pram, other baby paraphernalia, a night alone, a night with friends, a visa extension...Last Friday, dozens of Alanas friends and ex-colleagues took part in a baton relay that lasted six hours, helping to raise ,.Alana was touched by their efforts.She said: They made something beautul out of something horrendous.GOT a story  EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: border boris sturgeon scotland
story: The Prime Minister today bashed the First Minister after she refused to rule out the move.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAsked about it by Conservative MP Andrew Bowie at PMQs, Boris labelled her comments “absolutely astonishing”.He said: “There is no such thing as a border between England and Scotland.“There have been no such discussions with the Scottish administration about that but I would point out what he knows very well - there is no such thing as a border between England and Scotland.”According to The Times, Scottish Government sources say there are fears that progress in suppressing the deadly bug could be undone when the tourism season begins next month.The current rules see anyone coming into Scotland from overseas being put into quarantine for  days or face a £ fine.Now sources have warned thatcases continue to rise ministers are considering an option to apply the same rules to visitors from England.Boriss comments today sparked a furious response from Ms Sturgeon, who accused him of making “absurd and ridiculous political comments”.She said: “What there definitely is, is a geographical boundary to my powers as First Minister.“If the Prime Minister is questioning that now, Im not sure what he would sayI pitched up in Newcastle and started to try to implement Scottish Government policies in Newcastle.“And see what Ive just said there  Its absurd too, which is why we shouldnt be having these discussions.“We should all be focusing with an absolute laser-like focus on what we need to do within our own responsibilities and working together when necessary to stop a virus.”Ms Sturgeon also defended the possibility of bringing in the proposals.She added: “Given the nature of what were dealing with right now - just to remind the Prime Minister: an infectious virus - I would not be doing my job properlyI ruled things out that, as we see from countries around the world, are being used selectively in appropriate circumstances to try to contain a virus.”  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pubs can show football but quietly
story: Last week the Government issued new guidance for pubs and restaurants to stop the spread of coronavirus in venues when theyfrom July  - dubbed Super Saturday.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut the advice on whether pubs would be able to show the footie was unclear, and suggested it could be banned.Buried in the Governments guidance on reopening pubs and restaurants, it says that certain steps should be considered to stop the spread of the virus and prevent pubs from becoming hotspots.This may include preventing entertainment, such as broadcasts, that is likely to encourage audience behaviours increasing transmission risk, it says.Broadcasters have now received private assurances from Government that pubs will be allowed to show the matches, but it must be kept quiet.A Government insider said: Pubs and bars can show live sport but shouting and or chanting is not permitted for the same reason that live music isnt.Equally it must be played at a volume which enables normal conversation to take place.It means the commentary may be switched off during live games, and anyone shouting will be asked to keep it down.The PM has also announced that social distancing will be cut from two metres to one metre from July  to give venues the chance to let more people in.But gyms, nightclubs, nail salons and spas must remain closed for now as they still pose a risk to spread the virus.Some of the other rules included to keep people safe will include:But police are primed for more violence and antisocial behavior as pubs open up their doors once again.Appearing on ITV Good Morning Britain, John Apter, the Chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales warned: Weve had four months of pressure and frustration being built up. Weve seen an awful lot of violence on the street, an awful lot of it aimed at police officers.The day that the easing of the lockdown was announced for, the th of July, was almost made as a celebratory type way. Almost like a public holiday, and its far from a public holiday. And for policing, policing is tough at the best of times. The easing of this lockdown, especially when you introduce alcohol and opening bars and restaurants - andthe public think like this is going to be how it was in normal times, theyre very much mistaken.Theres going to be signicant restrictions which will create extra pressures.He added: Police is encouraging the Government to choose an alternative date.I completely accept that with universities closed and with many people not in the workplace, evenwe had on a weekday it might have not have made much of a dference, but it could have.On top of it all, its not far from payday, people will have just have been paid and its a full moon, which creates a whole host of other issues.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cardiff city sol bamba raid 90
story: Sol Bamba, , lost his Range Rover, Louis Vuitton bag and a Cartier watch when his family home was targeted by three burglars last year.A court heard the trio struck while Bambas team, Cardf City, were playing in Nice, France - and his we Chloe was away with their three children aged five to .But the Ivory Coast international - who has also played for Leeds and Leicester - came home to find their house ransacked.CCTV images from his home showed the three thieves wearing dark clothes, gloves and hoodies as they walked across his lawn into the house.Daniel Flynn, , was seen driving his Range Rover Sport away from the house after the property was plundered.Cardf Crown Court heard other private possessions were smashed leaving we Chloe devastated at the intrusion into her home.Judge Richard Twomlow said: I am told the house was ransacked and property smashed during the burglary.The exclusive Louis Vuitton bag and a Cartier watch were among her possessions taken in the raid - and left the family feeling violated.Cardf City were playing a pre-season friendly against OGC Nice on the day of the burglary. The defender, who speaks five languages, ed home to discover the damage.Flynn pleaded guilty at Cardf Crown Court to burgling Mr Bambas property on the outskirts of the Welsh capital in July last year.Accomplice Kyle Harris, , from Rumney, Cardf, was earlier jailed for two years after admitting his part in the burglary.The prosecution said Flynn had played a willing part and had been involved in many burglaries.Flynn will be sentenced later this month after pre-sentence reports into his background. The third man is still waiting to be brought to justice.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: andy burnham pm should show
story: NewsopinionAndy Burnham: PM should show true leadership and give our care heroes a pay riseWithout a pay rise for our social care, supermarket and bin workers, Boris Johnsons build build build speech is little more than a scrape of cement, writes Mayor of Greater Manchester Andy BurnhamShareCommentsByAndy Burnham:,  JUN NewsopinionWe’ll all be six foot under before it’s even half built ", url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSo, after the PM’s big speech, are we any closer to our much-promised Northern Powerhouse  If I was to be kind, I would say Boris yesterday scraped a bit of cement onto a brick or two. If I was to be more blunt, I would say that we’ll all be six foot under before it’s even half built at this glacial rate of progress. Boris was at pains to tell us he’s no communist. I think we knew that. What we discovered is that he’s no Franklin D Roosevelt either. President Roosevelt is famous for unlocking mega-bucks to lt America out of the Great Depression in the s. Our Prime Minister’s wallet, by contrast, is a bit thinner. While Roosevelt built the Hoover Dam, Johnson promised some bridge repairs in Sandwell. To be fair, there was some good news for Greater Manchester in the speech. We were give £m to clean up brownfield sites and build more homes on them. This will allow us to make some further inroads into tackling the housing crisis, although much more is needed. I was also pleased to hear the £ billion commitment to upgrade school buildings - though it didn’t escape my notice that it came almost  years to the day since Michael Gove scrapped Labour’s £ billion Building Schools for the Future programme. What the North of England needs more than anything is investment in our Victorian rail infrastructure which is responsible for the timetable chaos of recent years.  So we welcome the Prime Minister’s recognition of the “rail bottleneck” in Manchester City centre in his speech. But we’re not sure about his solution. We already have a plan in place to build two new s at Manchester Piccadilly to solve it. Instead of giving that the green light, the PM chose to allocate £m to develop an alternative plan. How does that fit with his much-vaunted Project Speed  Overall, and not for the first time with this Government, the hype before the speech overshadowed the real thing. There are only a certain number of times that you can promise to dual the A before people begin to switch off. As I said on Monday, “levelling up” needs to be about skin and bone as well as concrete and steel. People are crying out for help now and it would helpthe PM acknowledged this before promising any more shiny projects in the dim and distant future. One of the statistics which haunts me from this crisis was the Unison survey of care workers in the North West. It found % said they feared they wouldn’t be paidthey needed to self-isolate. Just think about that. We have a care service in England which has such poor employment conditions that it forces people to stay in work evenare ill. If the PM had started his speech by promising that, from now on, the heroes who work in our care homes looking after our relatives will get paid at least the same as a nurse, then I think the whole country would have risen to applaud him.

title: ex lib dem leader jo
story: NewsEx-Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson becomes professor at top management schoolShe had hoped to become Prime Minister, but six-and-a-half months after the disastrous general election which ended her political career, she will settle for being a visiting professorShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  JUL NewsJo Swinson was today unveiled as a professor at a top management school ", url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFormer Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson today got a new job – as a professor at a top management school. Prof Swinson, , won the partyaposs leadership race last July and claimed she could become Prime Minister.She hoped to scoop up pro-EU supporters, sweep to No and torpedo Brexit. However, when voters went to the polls at Decemberaposs general election, her partyaposs  MPs were cut to just  and she lost her East Dunbartonshire seat.It was the second time she had been dumped by electors in four years, after losing the constituency in  before regaining it in .  Today, she was unveiled as visiting professor at Cranfield School of Management, based at Cranfield University, Beds. Former Business Minister Prof Swinson said: “The world of work is changing rapidly and Covid- has sent that change into overdrive. “How organisations adapt will determine their ability to survive and thrive. “I’m delighted to be joining Cranfield School of Management and I’m looking forward to helping develop their thinking on issues that I have championed throughout my career such as gender equality and the role of technology in the workplace.”  The two Lib Dem MPs locked in the increasingly-bitter battle to succeed her as party boss, acting leader Sir Ed Davey and education spokeswoman Layla Moran, hailed her appointment. Sir Ed, who lost last yearaposs leadership race to Prof Swinson, tweeted his “huge congrats”, saying her “fantastic experience as a Business Minister  work on everything from AI to equality will be well used” at Cranfield.

Non-essential businesses - including pubs - will reopen their doors in England this weekend, and people will finally be able to reunite with family for longer periods of time. But whataposs next  Back in May, Prime Minister Boris Johnson revealed his -page road map plan for getting the UK out of lockdown, both socially and economically. Pubs, hairdressers, hotels, campsites, restaurants, cinemas, museums and galleries can reopen their doors on Saturday  July and two households will also be able to meet indoors and even stay overnight - as long as they maintain social distancing. title: public health englands future doubt
story: NewsPublic Health Englands future in doubt as No refuses to rule out scrapping itNo did not rule out major reforms before winter to the public health body - which was responsible for the testing regime across EnglandShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUL NewsIt comes after Boris Johnson attacked sluggish parts of the system ", url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe future of a key health body was thrown into doubt today after No refused to rule out scrapping or reforming it - as soon as this winter. Downing Street refused to guarantee Public Health England would continue in its current form after Tory MPs called for it to be scrapped.It comes after Boris Johnson yesterday said some parts of the state had been sluggish in responding to the coronavirus pandemic. He did not say which bits he meant.Public Health England has been responsible for much of the controversial testing programme in England, which saw widespread community testing axed in March. It was then slowly brought back as capacity increased. Briefing against PHE intensied overnight as a former minister told the Dailyit appeared destined for the chop. Iain Duncan Smith, the former Tory leader, added to the newspaper: I would abolish PHE tomorrow. What this has shown is thatministers are to take responsibility for things they must also have control, and they donapost have control over PHE. The newspaper reported that the Treasury was reviewing whether plans to establish a new PHE headquarters in Harlow, Essex, should go ahead. Boris Johnsonaposs official spokesman today insisted PHE was playing a key role but did not rule out whether it could undergo major reforms or be scrapped. He said: “PHE are playing a key role in our response working on important issues such as detection, surveillance, contact-tracing and testing. “They have been working hard to help protect the country and to provide insight in our efforts to beat the virus. “Separately, you’re aware that the roadmap we published in May says we must learn the right lessons from this crisis and act to ensure the government’s structures are fit to cope.

title: cruel man kept friends decomposing
story: NewsCruel man kept friends decomposing body in his house for eight daysMark Sheldon, , found pal Gareth Oldroyd, , on the sofa at his flat in Wakefield after a night of taking drugs, but did not report the tragedy as he was worried about getting in trouble, a court heardShareCommentsByBarnaby Kellaway:,  JUL NewsThe tragedy happened at a home in Wakefield, Yorkshire", url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA callous and cruel man kept his friendaposs decomposing body in his house for eight days - even as the dead manaposs distraught family desperately tried to find him. Mark Sheldon, , found pal Gareth Oldroyd, , dead on the sofa at his house after the pair had spent the evening together taking drugs, a court heard this week Sheldon and his housemate, Martin Webley, refused to contact emergency services about the tragedy for fear of getting into trouble with the police, it was heard. They covered Mr Oldroydaposs body with a blanket and continued to live in a bedroom at the house in Wakefield, West Yorkshire, after moving the TV out of the living room. The court heard Sheldon failed to raise the alarm despite the dead manaposs panicked loved ones filing a missing person report to the police. Authorities were eventually contacted by one of Sheldonaposs other friends, who became suspicious and challenged the defendant over his behaviour. Sheldon confessed to the man that Mr Oldroyd was dead in the living room and his body was eventually recovered more than a week after he stopped breathing. Appearing in the dock at Leeds Crown Court this week, the defendant was jailed for nine months after pleading guilty to an offence of preventing a lawful and decent burial. Prosecutor James Lake said officers went to the house on December , , where they noticed a strong smell and found Mr Oldroydaposs body in an advanced state of decomposition. Mr Lake said it appeared as though Sheldon and Mr Webley had continued to live at the property as there were left over meals and drinks in the kitchen. Mr Webley would have been facing the same charge but has since died from a drug overdose, the court heard. Mr Lake said: This was an offence that was callous, thoughtless and cruel, in particular to the family of the person who died. Mr Oldroydaposs father, Martin, provided a victim statement to the court describing how Sheldonaposs actions meant they were unable to grieve properly following the death. Mr Lake said: He cannot understand why Mr Webley and this defendant did not make any attempt to inform the police or call the ambulance and instead left a body to decompose. He and his family were unable to see Gareth after his death or visit him at a chapel of rest. Martinaposs statement stated: We do not feel we have been able to grieve his passing away. I am told that they panicked, but my personal thoughts were that they were just selfish and thinking about themselves. The court heard -year-old Mr Oldroyd leaves behind a three-year-old daughter.

title: 100 days lockdown powerful images

mainly England - have seen many of the restrictions lted.While things are far from back to normal and most of us are still missing the things and people we love, the majority of us are getting used to the new normal.Over the past  days weve seen Britain come together, with inspiring stories of NHS heroes and key workers, random acts of kindness and creativity in the most dficult of circumstances.However there has also been anger, upset and confusion stemmed from some peoples refusal to follow the le-saving rules, discrepancies in information and general frustration with the governments handling of the crisis.Weve looked back at some of the most important and defining moments from the lockdown.Queuing to get inside the supermarket became a weekly occurrence, with many stores turning their car parks into lanes so people could socially distance while they waited  of The children of key workers continued going to school, with many attending hub school with children from the local areas. title: homesick student cycles 2000 miles
story: NewsHomesick student cycles , miles from Aberdeen to Athens to see his family in lockdownCleon Papadimitriou, , set out on May  and cycled for  days from Aberdeen, where he is studying electronic engineering, to Melissia, near Athens, surviving on bread, peanut butter and sardinesShareCommentsByRyan Merrield:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsCleon Papadimitriou cycled , miles in  days", url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA homesick student beat the lockdown by cycling , miles from Britain to visit his family in Greece in  days. Cleon Papadimitriou, , got on his bike after getting fed up of waiting for travel restrictions to be lted. He left his student flat in Aberdeen on May  and took a ferry to Holland before cycling through Germany, Austria and Italy carrying a load of  kilograms. From there he took another ferry to Patras in Greece, arriving in Athens seven weeks after setting off. For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE. Cleon said: I like adventures so when I couldnapost fly home I decided to go by bike. I had a lot of punctures and had to put up with snow, hail and intense heat along the way. Sometimes the bicycle tire burst two or three times a day, and that not only cost me a lot of time but it wasn’t good for my morale either.  It was a lesson I had to learn to manage. Iaposm a bit saddle sore but it was worth it, he added. Cleon camped along his marathon journey and survived on bread, peanut butter and tins of sardines. His parents greeted him when he arrived in Melissia, north of the Greek capital, with a laurel crown and a large banner saying: Welcome Home Cleon: One more challenge accomplished! Cleon plans to fly back to Scotland to complete his electronic engineering degree at Aberdeen University when flights resume. He began studying there in September .

title: hotels reopening rules holidays open
story: Advertorial new rules hotels MUST follow to reopen - plus the amazing work some have been doing during lockdownYoull notice some changes next time you check-in to stay at a hotel after the government announced a raft of guidelinesShareByDave Masters:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL Advertorial", url"News, views and top stories . Dont miss our must-read newsletterWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailEverybody is crying out for a holiday after months of lockdown and staycations are set to soar with trips abroad looking unlikely for most. The good news is the government has given permission for hotels with en suite showering facilities, or one designated shower facility per guest room, to reopen. But it has issued strict guidelines for owners to follow in order to keep staff and visitors safe and stop the spread of Covid-. The seven key new rules are designed to help employers, employees and the self-employed in England only understand how to work as safely as possible and protect their customers while keeping to the recommended social distancing guidance applicable at the time. Below are the seven vital changes you will notice next time you stay at a hotel in England...plus we speak to a hotel in Glasgow to see how they have been adapting during the crisis. . Screens in reception  Hotels have been told to take measures to make reception areas safer, with increased cleaning, keeping the activity time as short as possible and where possible the addition of screens between guests and staff. . Lt limits Bosses have been told to consider minimising lt usage from reception, and urged to provide clear signage for new lt rules. . New room service delivery plans Where offering room service, the guidelines state measures such as dropping butler’s trays outside door should be introduced. Hotels are also encouraged to add tips to the bill. . Cleaning checklist for housekeeping  Housekeeping staff must follow government handwashing guidelines, and now make a checklist of all hand contact services to be cleaned when each guests vacates. . Swimming pools and sauna rules Hotels have been told to check the latest government guidance on opening of additional guest facilities . . Face masks for guests  Guests are to be encouraged to wear masks on communal corridors to help minimise the spread of Covid-. . Social distancing at bars Owners must ensure that any bar or dining area is only opened in a way compliant with UK government guidance on the hospitality sector. Hotel supports hospital heroes with meals  When the coronavirus pandemic hit, Laura McKenzie had a flood of cancelled bookings at her Glasgow hotel, Cathedral House. The McKenzie family had spent  months building up business at the boutique hotel, which offers a luxurious “home from home” atmosphere, so they were shattered. But within days Laura, who runs the hotel with husband Shane and two of their children Callum,  and -year-old Anna, was inspired to help out staff at nearby Glasgow Royal Infirmary. First, they block booked rooms for hospital staff at a reduced rate then with the help of a donation from Celtic FC Foundation, set to work making meals for them. “I made a few phone calls and straightaway we had the team we needed to start producing the meals. It was probably ten days from thinking: ‘This is horric, this is the end’ to thinking ‘We can do something good and support the local hospital here.’” Laura knows the pressure that NHS staff are under because her daughter, Emily, , is a junior doctor in Dundee, so she was desperate to help. With the hotel’s staff all on furlough, Laura assembled a team of volunteer chefs from the city. The Red Onion’s patron chef John Quigley was one of the first to volunteer and Laura worked with the head nurse at the Infirmary to set up the menu.  “We decided we were going to do  meals a day,” she says. “We did  veggie options and  meat options and bought little takeaway tubs and labelled them all up with little stickers that said: ‘With love from Cathedral House’. And every night at quarter to seven the driver from the hospital would come and take the big boxes of food away. He said there was always such a buzz. People were like: ‘Oh, the food’s coming! What have we got today ’” The hotel has now delivered more than , dishes such as jambalaya, bangers and mash and Thai curry. “It was a simple menu, all cooked fresh with lots of veggies and the sort of dishes you’d cook for yourself when you get home from work,” says Laura. Doctors staying at the hotel were delighted because Laura would text them to seethey wanted a dinner putting aside – and they could pop down to the kitchen to collect it. Laura’s home-from-home hospitality was a real comfort to her guests.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWe have lived in lockdown for  days, le before March  a distant memory. “Normal” le now means accepting that a trip to the shops means standing, face hidden under a mask, in a socially-distanced queue, or working from home, while home-schooling the kids, or keeping in touch with colleagues and loved-ones on Zoom calls. Things we took for granted – the night out at the pub, trip to the cinema, mini-break in a European capital – belong in the past. Even our vocabulary has changed, words like shielding, self-isolation, the R number and lockdown itself now common.The Oxford English Dictionary added  coronavirus words, including “elbow bump”, in April.Here are some other ways the lockdown has changed Britain in the past  days.Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog hereFinance With shops closed and long queues at supermarkets, more Brits than ever started doing their shopping online, or buying their groceries local. One in five British households bought groceries online in the past month, pumping up sales for home delivery by %, while small independent stores rang up % more sales in the three months to  June, according to analysts Kantar. Nearly half of debit card transactions are now made online, while older generations in particular have seen their internet spending rise, to % of transactions from just % a year ago. And with cash seen as a potential vector for spreading the virus, and the contactless limit raised to £, the decline of cash has accelerated too. Withdrawals from ATM fell as much as % year on year during the lockdown, according to data from cash machine network, Link. But while nearly two million UK households are set to emerge from restrictions better off after saving money, those with incomes less than £, are more likely to have borrowed money and face a dficult future. Economy  And figures have now shown the UK economy shrank .% between January and March, the joint largest fall since . The International Monetary Fundwarns the world is set to take a £. trillion Covid- hit, and Britain’s economy will plunge by .% in . Some experts say we should expect levels of unemployment of three million or more, while the Centre for Retail Research predicts as many as , shops could close this year. Debenhams, Laura Ashley and Cath Kidston are just some of those hit hard already. Workers furloughed fear redundancy once employers need to start paying some of their wages in August. Meanwhile, the way we work may have changed forever. Many have seen the benefits to work-le balance of working from home and video calls, with , working parents surveyed by Bright Horizons showing only around one in eight want toto pre-pandemic ‘normal’. One in  business premises in London have already permanently closed. Communication  We’ve all had to find new ways to communicate. Unknown to most before lockdown, millions are now familiar with video conferencing app Zoom, which by the end of April had over million daily meeting participants. And older people have also become tech-savvy, with % of elderly residents in of parts of the UK regularly using Zoom, WhatsApp and FaceTime to connect with loved ones.Lockdown has also given us the chance to meet our neighbours – whether it’s saying “hello” over the garden fence, going into the street to clap for carers, or getting together in community Whatsapp groups and Facebook pages.However, social media has had its downsides, with a study finding that those who believed in conspiracy theories were more likely to get Covid- information from Facebook or YouTube. Of those, % believed coronavirus was created in a lab and % claimed it didn’t exist at all. Sport  When the Premier League restarted on June  there were cheers from football fans across the country. And no more so than when Liverpool won their first Premier League title in  years. But things were far from normal as matches took place behind closed doors and fans could pay to have a cardboard cut-out of themselves in the stadium seats of their favourite team. And imagine telling a football fan back in January that they’d be able to use the red button to turn fake crowd noises on and off during a match Meanwhile, while some big events such Royal Ascot and the darts PDC tour were given the green light to go ahead, others, such as Wimbledon and the Olympics were forced to reschedule.Relationships  More than % of people say that lockdown has had a positive effect on their lives. And, of these respondents, more than half said they were able to spend more quality time with the loved ones they lived with. Meanwhile, absence has made the heart grow fonder and helped us appreciate family members more than ever. And % of new couples say the pandemic has made their relationship stronger. But there’s been some hurdles to overcome. Parents have been homeschooling their kids for  days. Yet only % of working class parents feel confident in doing so. And sadly, there’s been a % increase in orce inquiries. The Environment  This was our lockdown silver lining. Studies found daily global carbon dioxide emissions fell by % compared with  levels thanks to the shut down of industry and traffic at the start. As le stilled, wildle began reclaiming the empty spaces. Goats took to the streets of Llandudno, buzzards ed to Hampstead Heath and after the National Trust closed their properties, rangers reported rare animal sightings. While CO levels still rose, reaching . parts per million in May - .ppm higher than the peak of .ppm in  - scientists say that without Covid-, the rise might have reached .ppm. NHS and key workers  The nation’s clap – or pan rattle – for carers, thanking our NHS, social care and key workers, became strict Thursday night routine. Rainbows in our windows thanked them. As many of us worked from home, we appreciated others were taking a risk to support us and save lives. After the Prime Minister himself thanked the NHS for saving his own, our health service can surely never be undervalued again. But too many workers paid with their lives. Most – some analysis suggests % - from BAME groups. Schools universities  Parents tried their best to homeschool, but four in ten pupils across England have not been in regular contact with their teachers since schools shut. Another report estimates around one in five UK pupils have done no schoolwork or managed less than an hour a day. While seven out of  state school pupils have had just one online lesson or less per day, almost a third of private schools have been providing four or more, exposing a widening gap between the rich and poor. Meanwhile, older students, forced to take virtual exams and accept predicted marks, fear downgrades. Many are planning to defer university, too, as online learning and student ‘bubbles’ are considered. Cambridge University has already announced all learning will be online until summer . Politics  The daily press briefing has meant we have seen more of the government than ever. Record numbers of million of us were glued initially – although that later shrunk to million.Meanwhile, confidence in Boris Johnson and the Tories has shrunk, too.At the start of lockdown, three in four Brits agreed with government handling of the pandemic. A recent YouGov poll shows the British government has the lowest domestic approval rating in the world  for its handling of Covid-.The PM’s approval ratings sit at just %, not helped by the revelation his top aide Dominic Cummings flouted lockdown rules. An Opinium poll showed % of voters think Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer would be better at leading the country, compared to % for Boris.Hobbies at home As we’re unable to go out, we’ve had to find new ways to amuse ourselves. Flour production had to increase  fold to keep up with the surge in home baking. And, by April, there were over .million photos tagged “sourdough” on Instagram.Lockdown has also given us the time to start those tedious household jobs and the three-hour long queue outside Ikea and BQ showed just how much DIY we had to do. We’ve also been making the most of home comforts, with slipper sales doubling in some stores, such as John Lewis and a % increase in TV viewing. Meanwhile, for those who wanted a bit of fun there have been countless Zoom quizzes, and the sale of alcohol at supermarkets soared. For animal lovers, working from home has also provided the perfect opportunity to get a pet – with online searches for getting a puppy surging %. Exercise  Gyms closing saw theof the home workout. Many elite gyms, such as Barry’s Bootcamp and Rebel started streaming their classes on social media for free.Before lockdown, few people had heard of Joe Wicks, who has given millions of children the taste of a daily exercise routine, while celebrities such as Tyson Fury, Naomi Campbell and Gregg Wallace, also started sharing their workout regimes with fans.Perhaps the most unlikely motivator was Boris Johnson, who announced lockdown urging people to exercise once a day. A Bupa study found that % of Brits have upped their usual exercise and bike sales have increased by %. On the down side, .million eager exercisers have injured themselves during lockdown, with men twice as likely as women to get hurt. Royals  Despite not being able to attend public engagements, the Royals have made sure to maintain their duties by switching to video calls during lockdown. William, Kate, Charles, Camilla and other members of the royal family kept busy with their charity work online - even turning into bingo callers for a care home in Cardf. And members of the royal family have also been volunteering, particularly the Countess of Wessex, who has been organising PPE shipments and working in a charity shop.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAlton Towers has given visitors an insight as to how the theme park will look when it reopens on Saturday. The popular tourist attraction will open its doors on July  for the first time in more than three months as lockdown measures ease in England. Pictures taken from inside the park show guests will have a completely dferent experience. Like zoos, anyone wanting to visit Alton Towers will have to pre-book for entry, with the park opening at limited capacity. Queues will be spaced out to ensure people are social distancing, and face masks will be compulsory for anyone over the age of six on certain rides, including Nemesis, Galactica, Oblivion, The Smiler, Wicker Man, Rita, THTEEN and Runaway Mine Train. At the park entrance, temperature checks will be carried out with a non-touch thermometer. Anyone with a temperature over . degrees will be denied entry.The majority of rides and outdoor attractions will reopen, but some indoor facilities will stay shut, BirminghamLive reports.Staff will also wear PPE and rides will be thoroughly cleaned regularly.  Last month, incredible drone footage showed an eerily empty Alton Towers as operators worked on the rides at dizzying heights. Other rollercoasters such as The Smiler sit eerily empty while carriages can be seen going around tracks on other rides - but with no passengers on board. The Alton Towers website reads: In line with the latest Government guidance, we are delighted to confirm that Alton Towers Resort will reopen on the  July . We can’t wait to welcome you back.This follows the successful opening of the Alton Towers Gardens earlier this month, and is in line with the UK Government guidance on the reopening of open-air attractions.  From  July, the rest of the theme park will reopen, including the majority of our rides and outdoor attractions, although some indoor facilities must remain closed for now.  We will reopen with signicantly reduced numbers and a range of hygiene and safety measures to protect you and our employees.All guests must bring a suitable mask with them when they visit our attraction. Only securely fitted face masks should be worn on rides for safety reasons and we would recommend removing face masks on water rides in case they get wet.

Nearly a fthof people want to change the style of their home, according to the research, carried out ahead of New Homes Week Unlocked between July  and , which showcases the benefits of new build homes. Interest in interior design appears to have particularly increased among Millennials, with nearly a quarterof  to -year-olds saying they have become more interested in this during the lockdown, the survey of , people across the UK found.The findings were released as Halax said that in June, mortgage applications from first-time buyers nearly doubled. Halax saw a % increase from May as buyers looked to step on to the housing ladder. Halax said East Anglia, the North West and the North East in England are proving some of the most popular choices for those looking for a new home after lockdown, with mortgage applications already higher in these regions than levels seen before the pandemic.A survey from Halax of more than , people found that over halfof workers who had been working from home now think that there is less need for people to live in a city. Many said that being close to their office is no longer an important factor when purchasing a property.Many Brits are working from their bedrooms:Walkers confirms  members of workforce test positiveLeicester-based crisp-maker Walkers said  members of its ,-strong workforce had tested positive for coronavirus. The figure - equivalent to % of its employees - relates to testing during the course of June. Public health officials are understood to believe that the cases reflect community transmission of coronavirus. It is also understood that workers with confirmed or suspected cases of Covid- are self-isolating at home, while on full pay. :NHS trust blames second, late peak for high death figuresAn NHS trust is blaming a #xCsecond, late peak#xD after its hospitals recorded more than % of weekly Covid- deaths for the whole of England. East Kent Hospitals said it saw high numbers of patients with coronavirus in late May and cited the area#xs elderly demographic. In the week to June ,  people died at hospitals run by the trust after testing positive for the disease, Government figures published on Tuesday show. This was nearly double the NHS trust with the second highest figure, George Eliot Hospital NHS Trust in Warwickshire, which recorded  deaths.East Kent Hospitals NHS Trust :KEY EVENTCoronavirus UK death toll rises by  to , in week-on-week increaseThe total UK coronavirus death toll has risen by  to a total of ,.It is a week-on-week rise compared to last Wednesday.Read the full story here. Experts say more local lockdowns in England can be expected:UK has enough stocks of remdesivir drug after US buys nearly all of itThe UK has enough stocks of the drug remdesivir, the Department of Health has confirmed, after the US bought nearly all the manufacturing stock for the next three months.The Department of Health said it had secured supplies of remdesivir in advance and had enough to treat every NHS patient who needs it.It comes after the US Department of Health and Human Servicessaid it had secured more than , treatment courses of remdesivir for American hospitals.This represents % of the US pharmaceutical firm Gilead#xs projected production for July , % of production in August , and % of production in September , alongside an allocation for clinical trials.Remdesivir is an anti-viral drug that was developed for use against Ebola.It has been approved for use in Covid- patients by the US and the UK, among other countries, after data suggested it can cut recovery time by about four days.However, there is no clinical trial data as yet to suggest it improves survival from coronavirus. :KEY EVENTUK coronavirus hospital death toll up by  in lowest Wednesday rise since lockdownThe UK coronavirus hospital death toll has risen by  to a total of ,.In England  more people died in hospitals from Covid-, in Scotland one more patient died, and six more patients also died in Wales. No new deaths were reported in Northern Ireland.It#xs the lowest rise on Wednesday since the lockdown began.On recent Wednesdays, the hospital death toll increased by  on June ,  on June ,  on June ,  on June ,  on May  and  on May .The biggest rise on a Wednesday was  on April , when the UK was in the deadliest days of its outbreak.A further  people, who tested positive for the Coronavirushave died, bringing the total number of confirmed reported deaths in hospitals in England to ,. Click here for the full story. :KEY EVENTWalkers crisps confirms coronavirus outbreak at Leicester factorySnack giant Walkers has confirmed  positive cases of Covid- at its factory in Leicester.The firm, which employs , people across the site in the Beaumont Leys area of the city, said it had seen a #xCsteady increase#xD in the number of confirmed cases during June.Walkers claimed its track and trace procedure indicated the transmission of the virus was #xCnot in our factory#xD.Instead, it believes the rise #xCcoincides with the roll-out and uptake of testing#xD in Leicester. Click here for the full story. :Six more Covid- deaths confirmed in WalesA further six patients have died after testing positive for coronavirus in Wales, health officials have announced.Scotland earlier announced that two more people had died after being diagnosed with the killer virus.:Boris Johnson snubs calls to give m people a £, coronavirus benefit boostBoris Johnson has snubbed calls to boost benefits for million needy people during the coronavirus crisis.The government agreed to increase Universal Credit and Working Tax Credit by #xA a week for one year to help people cope during the pandemic.But they#xve refused to match the increase for so-called #xlegacy benefits#x - despite the fact these are still claimed by huge numbers who haven#xt moved to six-in-one benefit UC.The vast majority of the roughly million people still on legacy benefits claim Employment Support Allowance , meaning they are chronically sick or disabled.For the full story, click here:Government under fire for allowing pubs to reopen on a SaturdayA police and crime commissioner has criticised the Government#xs decision to reopen bars on a Saturday - and warned of a #xClikely threat of serious disorder#xD. David Jamieson, the elected commissioner for the West Midlands Police area, urged people to act sensibly when pubs finally reopen after lockdown. The Labour commissioner said: #xCI am in favour of the gradual lting of the lockdown, based on the science, but not in the way the Government have proceeded.#xD Warning that Saturday is set to be the busiest day of the year for West Midlands Police, Mr Jamieson added: #xCSignicant preparations are being put in place and we are working closely with pubs to mitigate the threat of disorder. #xCIt would have been sensible for the Government to schedule the first day of pub openings for midweek or the Monday afterwards rather than a Saturday.#xDDavid Jamieson has hit out at the government :Boris Johnson blames problems getting people to understandLeicester was forced into lockdown because of #xCproblems getting people to understand#xD what to do, Boris Johnson claimed today.The Prime Minister said the city had #xCparticular#xD problems that meant a fresh outbreak of the virus was not contained quickly enough.It was not immediately clear what the Prime Minister was referring to.Leicester Labour MP Jon Ashworth has highlighted the city is #xCproudly erse#xD and has high poverty rates - two things that put its citizens more at risk from Covid-.For the full story, click here:One more death in Scotland, Nicola Sturgeon announcesA total of , patients have died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up by one from Tuesday, Nicola Sturgeon said.Speaking at the Scottish Government#xs coronavirus briefing, the First Minister said eight more people had tested positive for the virus in  hours, taking the total to ,.A total of  patients are in Scottish hospitals with confirmed or suspected Covid-, a fall of  in  hours, she added.Of these,  are intensive care, a drop of two.The death figure announced by the First Minister dfers from the weekly statistics released on Wednesday by the National Records of Scotland, as the former covers patients who have tested positive and the latter involves all registered deaths where Covid- is mentioned on the death certicate, whether confirmed or suspected.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon:Labour leader highlights job losses across UKKeir Starmer highlighted job losses at Airbus, easyJet and others, adding in the Commons: #xCThere was nothing in the Prime Minister#xs speech for the . million people in hospitality or the . million in retail.#xCNext week#xs financial statement could be the last chance to save millions of jobs. Will the Prime Minister start now by extending the furlough scheme for those parts of the economy which are still most at risk #xD Boris Johnson said the best thing to do was helpthe economy to health by ensuring people are back in work and the virus is #xCdefeated and under control#xD, adding Labour could #xCstop equivocating, doing one thing one week and one thing another week#xD.Airbus is among the companies which has announced job losses :Keir Starmer says hes not blind to the riskSir Keir Starmer said the issue is a #xCconcern#xD as there is nationwide lting of lockdown restrictions this weekend #xCwithout an app, without clear data for local authorities or the world-beating system we were promised#xD.He added: #xCI support the easing of restrictions but unlike the Prime Minister, I#xm not blind to the risks and I don#xt think anybody  should be.#xDSir Keir said: #xCOf the , new cases of Covid infections per week in mid June, just , were reached and asked to provide details. So now three quarters of people with Covid- are not being reached. How does the Prime Minister explain that #xDSir Keir Starmer Boris Johnson replied: #xCAs he knows very well the test, track and trace operation is actually reaching huge numbers of people and causing them to self-isolate in ways I don#xt think he conceivably could have expected a month ago when this system was set up.Mr Johnson added that the Test and Trace system #xChas now reached , contacts, , contacts who have undertaken to self-isolate to stop the disease spreading#xD.:Flippant PM blasted over Bournemouth beaches incidentBoris Johnson was accused of #xCbatting away#xD legitimate concerns from seaside resorts.Sir Keir Starmer said: #xCThe Prime Minister can#xt just bat away challenge. These are matters of le and death, other people#xs livelihoods. #xCAn example of this, last week the Member for Hoveasked the Prime Minister how can seaside towns be expected to cope with likely influx of visitors to beaches and parks during the hot weather  #xCThe Prime Minister replied, show some guts. Two days later Bournemouth beach was closed with , visitors, a major incident was declared. #xCDoes the Prime Minister now regret being so flippant #xD Mr Johnson replied that he was making it #xCabsolutely clear that as we go forward with our plan, our cautious plan for opening up the economy, it is very, very important that people who do represent seaside communities, places where UK tourists will want to go, should be as welcoming as they can possibly be#xDThousands packed onto beaches in Bournemouth :New figures show where most cases are being foundPublic Health England has released a weekly snapshot of new Covid- cases in England, by local authority.The snapshot shows the rate of new cases in each area, based on tests that have been carried out in laboratoriesand in the wider community .As such it gives a more comprehensive overview of the country than the daily figures for local areas that are published on the Department of Health website, which are based only on pillar  testing.The latest Public Health England snapshot is for the week ending June , and shows four areas in the top category of  or more cases per , population:BarnsleyBradfordLeicesterRochdaleThere are six areas in the next category :BedfordBlackburn with DarwenKirkleesOldhamRotherhamTamesideA new snapshot for the week ending June  is due to be published on Thursday, as part of Public Health England#xs weekly coronavirus surveillance report.:PM hopes for biggest ever thank you day for NHSBoris Johnson said he hopes the nation will come together for the #xCbiggest ever thank you day#xD for the NHS on Sunday. He told Prime Minister#xs Questions: #xCIt will provide the perfect moment to thank not just our amazing NHS and care workers but also those key workers who have helped in the national effort in our fight against coronavirus and all those across the country who have gone the extra mile for their local communities in these challenging times. #xCI#xm sure we can agree across this House the NHS represents the very best of us and we will always be there to support it.#xD Sunday July  marks the nd anniversary of the NHS.The under-fire Prime Minister has been criticised by the Labour Party leader :Starmer voices alarm over track and trace shortcomingsThe Labour leader told the House of Commons he was alarmed that two thirds of people can#xt be contacted because a #xCworld beating#xD test and trace system isn#xt in place.He said: #xCI support the easing of restrictions, but unlike the Prime Minister I#xm not blind to the risks.#xD:Number of deaths falling in ScotlandA total of , people have died in Scotland with confirmed or suspected coronavirus, according to the National Records of Scotland .Between June  and June   deaths relating to Covid- were registered, down  on the previous week, marking the ninth weekly consecutive fall and the lowest weekly total since mid-March.This week is the first time since March - that the total number of deaths registered, at ,, was below the five-year weekly average, of ,.The NRS statistics are published weekly and account for all deaths registered in Scotland where Covid- was mentioned on the death certicate.They dfer from the lab-confirmed coronavirus deaths announced daily by the Scottish Government as they include suspected or probable cases of Covid-.Police patrol in Edinburgh as shops reopen :PMQs underway as Labour accuses government of not sharing dataPMQs is now underway.Labour leader Keir Starmer is straight on the attack, saying data about infection levels have not been shared with local authorities.#xCThe Prime Minister can#xt just bat away people#xs concerns,#xD the opposition leader said.Labour leader Keir Starmer :How Alton Towers will look when it reopens to thrillseekers on SaturdayAlton Towers has given visitors an insight as to how the theme park will look when it reopens on Saturday.The popular tourist attraction will open its doors on July  for the first time in more than three months as lockdown measures ease in England.Pictures taken from inside the park show guests will have a completely dferent experience.Like zoos, anyone wanting to visit Alton Towers will have to pre-book for entry, with the park opening at limited capacity.For the full story, click here:One in eight care home residents havent been testedAround one in eight care home residents have not yet been tested for coronavirus, a survey of more than  care homes has found. The National Care Forum , which represents  of the UK#xs social care charities, surveyed members on the whole home-testing experience for staff and residents. Respondents said , staffand ,of residents in care homes are still awaiting Covid- tests. This is despite all homes with residents over  having been offered testing, and could be due to struggles to access tests and staff absences.Care staff are facing huge challenges in the wake of pandemic:US buys up virtually all stocks of anti-viral drug remdesivirThe Trump administration has bought up virtually all stocks for the next three months of a drug shown to work against Covid-.The US Department of Health and Human Servicessaid it had secured more than , treatment courses of remdesivir for American hospitals.This represents % of the US pharmaceutical firm Gilead#xs projected data as yet to suggest it improves survival from coronavirus.HHS secretary Alex Azar said in a statement: #xCPresident Trump has struck an amazing deal to ensure Americans have access to the first authorised therapeutic for Covid-.#xCTo the extent possible, we want to ensure that any American patient who needs remdesivir can get it.#xCThe Trump administration is doing everything in our power to learn more about le-saving therapeutics for Covid- and secure access to these options for the American people.#xDRead the full story here.Donald Trump :KEY EVENTTwo more places of concern after Leicester lockdownA top scientist has warned two more places in England are #xCclearly of concern#xD because of high rates of coronavirus.Imperial College London#xs Professor Neil Ferguson, who was a government adviser at the start of the pandemic, says it is only a matter of time until more places impose local lockdowns as Leicester has done following a spike of Covid- cases.And it is feared both Doncaster and Bradford could both see similar lockdowns following a worrying rise in the number of cases.For the full story, click hereExperts say more local lockdowns in England can be expected:Coronavirus-infected coughs can spray ft awayyou dont wear a face maskThe best face masks for stopping the spread of Covid- are well-fitting cone-style and home-made versions made from multiple fabric layers, according to a new study.Researchers analysed which were the best - and worst - face masks for minimising the spread of droplets from coughs or sneezes to mitigate the transmission of the virus.Tests showed that the least effective ieties were loosely-folded face masks and bandana-style coverings which provide minimal stopping-capability for respiratory droplets.The study, published in the journal Physics of Fluids, also discovered that coughs can potentially travel up to  feet, around . metres,unobstructed - much further than the new one-metre social distancing guideline.For the full story, click hereWith a folded cotton handkerchief, droplets traveled  foot,  inches:Turkey expects to welcome Brits again soonTurkey is hoping to welcome British tourists again shortly and expects to be on the list of destinations to be exempted from the UK#xs quarantine measures. The nation#xs ambassador to the UK said on Wednesday that his country believes it will be among those to form so-called air bridges when an announcement is made later this week. Umit Yalcin insisted it is safe to open up travel with Turkey despite a recent spike in cases after lockdown restrictions to combat the spread of Covid- were eased. The Government has imposed a -day quarantine on anyone entering the UK, apart from a few exemptions. But Prime Minister Boris Johnson is under pressure from the travel industry and from within his own party to ease the restriction to boost tourism and the economy.A nurse in protective gear in Istanbul, Turkey :Lack of testing left UK relatively blind following outbreak, says scientistA key scientist in the coronavirus response has said the UK was #xCrelatively blind#xD in late February over how much infection there was in the community because of a failure to quickly increase testing.Imperial College London#xs Professor Neil Ferguson, who used to advise the Government, told BBC Radio #xs Today programme: #xCWithout a doubt we didn#xt ramp up testing fast enough and therefore we were relatively blind in late February and early March about truly how much infection was happening in the community in this country brought in from Spain and Italy and other countries.#xCIt was only once we started hospital surveillance that we really got a good handle on that, and from that point onwards we acted very quickly however, it was just a little too late.#xDProfessor Neil Ferguson said the UK was relatively blind :Germanys unemployment rate lower than expectedThe number of people out of work in Germany rose far less than expected in June, data showed on Wednesday, allaying fears that the coronavirus pandemic would erode the labour market in Europe#xs largest economy. This meant that . million people were out of work in June. A Reuters poll had forecast an increase of ,, which would have pushed the unemployment rate to .%.Unemployment has not risen as quickly as expected in Germany :Ten thousand jobs gone in a week - all the companies cutting staffIn the past few days a string of major firms have announced they will be cutting staff of closing for good as a result of coronavirus.Up until now, millions of jobs had been protected from the fallout of coronavirus by the furlough scheme - but with a firm end date for that now in sight employers are facing tough decisions.So far this week easyJet and Upper Crust have announced up to , jobs could be lost between them, while high street chains Harvey#xs and TM Lewin went into administration. Worryingly, they#xre not alone.Money expert Martin Lewis warned this could just be the start.For the full story, click hereCompanies have announced they are shedding jobs :Yvette Cooper calls on government to stop screwing this upLabour MP Yvette Cooper tweeted that health authorities in her constituency in Wakefield, West Yorkshire, had been trying to get hold of local Pillar  testing data - the results from swab tests of the wider population - but had not been able to. She tweeted: #xCOur local public health teams, council, NHS doctors  managers in Wakefield have had to fight for months to try to get this data. In public health crisis, most important thing is knowing where infection is. Appalling  incomprehensible that basic info hasn#xt been provided. #xCThe idea this could have been Ministerial choice rather than failure of competence is even more shocking. What on earth is going on  Transparency  trust are basic currencies for dealing with public health crises. Pls, pls Govt, dont keep screwing this up.#xDLabours Yvette Cooper has said crucial data is not being made available More OnPoliticsCoronavirus

There are photographs of Lady Diana Spencer from the days leading up to her wedding to Prince Charles in which she is wearing two watches on one wrist Of course, one of them was hers - a pretty, delicate metallic watch with a thin strap. The other, more masculine, watch with a chunky brown leather strap belonged to Prince Charles. At the time she was snapped wearing the watches, the couple were engaged and got married later that month. And thereaposs a sweet reason for the doubling up of accessories. But her heart was shattered just a few days before she said her vows when she walked into his private secretary Michael Colborneaposs office. She saw a package sitting on the desk with Camillaaposs name written on it, and demanded to see what was inside of it. She found a gold bracelet engraved with the letters G and F, which stood for Gladys and Fred - the nicknames Charles and Camilla used for each other. Imperial College Londonaposs Professor Neil Ferguson, who was a government adviser at the start of the pandemic, says it is only a matter of time until more places impose local lockdowns as Leicester has done following a spike of Covid- cases. Leicesteraposs flare-up means it will not emerge from parts of lockdown as swtly as the rest of England on July , when pubs, restaurants, hairdressers and other non-essential businesses will reopen. Residents have been told to stay at home, with schools and shops to shut this week with the city being one of the countryaposs Covid- epicentres. And it is feared both Doncaster and Bradford could both see similar lockdowns following a worrying rise in the number of cases. My dear mother has been a Dundee icon for many, many years,# she said.#She meant so many things to so many dferent people, all positive.#Mum just kept on dancing for as long as she could.#She was teaching dance right up until a week before lockdown. She was a real trooper. I am so proud of her. She was a strong and very giving lady and everyone she taught loved her.#She was a great role model for everyone she taught and I never saw her bitter or angry.#Doreen was diagnosed with a terminal illness seven weeks ago and was told only four days later that there was no treatment available.Linda said: #I had to get special permission to come home to be with her and she was absolutely delighted when I made it. I was so worried I wouldn#t be able to get here. I#m so glad I got to be with her at the end.#She was delighted when on June  the girls from the Dundee Sparkletts twirling group managed to get along to see her through the window.#She had a dferent story for each of the girls, that#s just what she was like. She was so uncomplaining about everything.#I am a nurse back home in Australia and I can honestly say she was the easiest patient I have ever had.#Doreen grew up in Downfield, the daughter of Tom Donaldson, who ran a bakery in Haldane.She began competitive dancing at a very young age and started teaching when she was .Doreen#s first love had been Highland dancing, which took her all over the world including Russia, America, China, Turkey and Italy as well as to other European cities.Linda said: #She was heavily involved in cultural dance exchanges. She was also a dance examiner and travelled widely with that.#As well as Highland dance, Doreen taught twirling, tap, line dancing and majorettes, and more recently was involved with the Dundee Sparkletts troupe.Linda added: #Mum was a member of the Gay Gordon#s Dancers, Downfield Musical Society  and her highland dancers, back in the late #s and early #s, were used on some of the Alexander Brothers shows and Ronnie Coburn shows across Scotland.#She also sang across Scotland on some of these shows.#Doreen also worked for a time as a silver service waitress in Dundee and in H Samuel the jeweller.As well as Linda, Doreen had two sons, Keith and Alan, four grandchildren and three great grandchildren.A spokesman for Dundee Sparkletts said: #She was an inspiration to everyone she met.#The girls at Dundee Sparkletts loved going to her class each week learning lots of techniques while having fun.#Not only was she their teacher, she treated every one of the girls as her own, building their confidence, encouraging them even when times were challenging and getting them all to believe in themselves.#Doreen#s funeral, which is private because of Covid- restrictions, is to be held next week.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite.
